inputs.headline: Noem: Guantánamo Bay on the table to house deportees
inputs.content:
Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem signaled Wednesday morning that the Trump administration is considering using the Guantánamo Bay detention camp to house undocumented immigrants whom officials are seeking to deport.
Asked directly whether Guantánamo Bay was an option for sending undocumented immigrants apprehended by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents, Noem told Fox News’s “Fox & Friends” that President Donald Trump and his administration are looking at all their options for expelling people who are in the United States illegally, particularly those from countries that do not currently accept deportees, such as Venezuela and Cuba.
“We’re evaluating and talking about that right now. It’s the president’s decision, but it’s an asset, and we’re going to continue to look at how we can use all of our assets to keep America safe,” Noem said.
Guantánamo Bay is known for its military prison within the naval base on the coast of Cuba, where suspected terrorists have been held in the years since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. It also has a separate migrant processing facility, which the Biden administration used to process some asylum seekers.

inputs.headline: Supreme Court delays decision on Trump’s firing of watchdog agency leader
inputs.content: A divided Supreme Court on Friday put off ruling on the Trump administration’s request to allow the president to remove the leader of an independent government watchdog agency until at least after a lower-court hearing next week. It is the first case to reach the justices involving President Donald Trump’s expansive efforts to reshape the federal bureaucracy. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Hegseth to visit Guantanamo Bay as migrant detention takes shape
inputs.content:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth is expected to visit the naval base at Guantánamo Bay as soon as Wednesday as the Trump administration’s effort to detain migrants there continues to take shape, two military officials familiar with that matter said.
The trip will come after the Trump administration dispatched hundreds of U.S. Marines to the installation to assist in an operation detaining what Hegseth has called “high-threat” migrants due for deportation. Administration officials, seeking to project strength, put them in a prison at Guantánamo Bay that has been used to house suspected terrorists after the attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, saying that an initial wave was all from the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua.
Hegseth is expected to highlight the mission and how it is taking shape, said the military officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the issue. Some troops at Guantánamo Bay were informed of the visit on Tuesday, one of the officials said.

inputs.headline: Musk throws cold water on funding for Trump AI initiative
inputs.content: Elon Musk, the Tesla CEO and top ally of President Donald Trump, is casting doubt on the funding source for a massive artificial intelligence project that Trump announced Tuesday. “They don’t actually have the money,” Musk said late Tuesday on X, responding to an announcement about the initiative from OpenAI, one of the partners in the venture. The project, deemed “Stargate,” seeks to spend as much as $500 billion over the next four years to build up to 20 new data centers to support AI projects. Trump announced it at the White House alongside OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Oracle Chairman Larry Ellison and SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son. In a follow-up X post, Musk made clear that he was referring to SoftBank, a Japanese technology company with whom Trump has previously touted other deals. Musk and Altman have long feuded over OpenAI, an artificial intelligence research organization. They were co-chairs of OpenAI when it launched in 2015, but Musk departed years later and sued the company last year, accusing it of straying from its founding mission. Musk was one of the largest donors to Trump’s 2024 campaign effort and is now leading a government efficiency commission in the new administration.

inputs.headline: Trans health, research programs ordered to stop by Trump administration
inputs.content: The Trump administration is moving forward with its campaign to eradicate federal funding intended to improve the lives and health of transgender people, including by sending notices in recent days that terminate grants for transgender health services and research. The National Institutes of Health, for example, has demanded a halt to a large-scale study that was examining ways to prevent HIV infections in transgender youths of color before it could enroll participants this week. California clinics lost funding to provide care to hundreds of transgender patients. A federal scientific journal blocked publication of a paper that details the value of teaching transgender health. Read the full story

inputs.headline: N.Y. Mayor Eric Adams pushes for permanent dismissal of his corruption case
inputs.content:
NEW YORK — Mayor Eric Adams’s attorney argued Wednesday that the case against him should be dismissed permanently, alleging that leaks of a former top prosecutor’s resignation letter discussing the indictment prevented any future fair trial.
The motion filed by Adams lawyer Alex Spiro argued that the mayor’s right to a fair trial was tainted by former acting U.S. attorney Danielle Sassoon’s leaked Feb. 12 letter that said the case was strong and that her office was prepared to file additional charges for obstruction.
Sassoon also said she believed a quid pro quo existed between a top figure at the Justice Department and Adams, and that the mayor committed to help with President Donald Trump’s immigration efforts in exchange for seeing his case dismissed.
Adams and the Justice Department have denied a quid quo pro exists, but the ordeal and the government’s decision to abandon the public corruption matter have drawn an immense amount of controversy.
Acting deputy attorney general Emil Bove argued in court last week without offering proof that the case was politically motivated and would interfere with the 2025 mayoral election. Bove asked Judge Dale Ho to dismiss the case “without prejudice,” which would leave open a possible future revival of the matter.
Spiro argued in his letter to Ho on Wednesday that the case should be dismissed “with prejudice” instead, because “the government’s conduct has destroyed whatever presumption of innocence Mayor Adams had left.”
Ho cannot ultimately deny Bove’s request, but he did not immediately toss the case. He instead assigned an independent lawyer to evaluate arguments against the government’s dismissal request.

inputs.headline: GOP lawmakers scramble to protect foreign aid as food relief languishes
inputs.content: As GOP lawmakers in Washington try to protect a key food aid program from the Trump administration’s cutbacks, international humanitarian organizations say the ongoing disruptions in assistance are devastating countries that are on the verge of famine. The administration’s move in late January to gut the U.S. Agency for International Development — laying off thousands of workers and freezing funding in more than 100 countries — immediately jeopardized Food for Peace. For more than 70 years, the $2 billion program has purchased surplus commodities from American farmers for distribution overseas. Late Thursday, U.S. District Judge Amir Ali ordered administration officials to temporarily lift their freeze on U.S. aid and development programs abroad. He alluded to the “shockwave” caused by their action and said they “have not offered any explanation for why a blanket suspension of all congressionally appropriated foreign aid … was a rational precursor to reviewing programs.” President Donald Trump and top adviser Elon Musk, a tech billionaire, have been highly critical of USAID’s work, with Trump baselessly claiming the agency had committed “tremendous fraud.” Despite a State Department waiver for emergency food assistance, those shipments still had been delayed around the world, a USAID inspector general wrote in a report Monday — a day before he was dismissed. The bottleneck, Paul K. Martin wrote, put more than $489 million in food assistance at risk of spoilage or theft as it waited at ports, in transit and in warehouses. In defending itself in court, Ali noted, the government acknowledged that the waiver process “may have had ‘hiccups.’” Aid groups had said Thursday that some food deliveries were starting to move through shipping channels but that millions more pounds of corn, lentils and pinto beans remained stuck because the agency’s payment system was not functioning. The waiver for lifesaving assistance that was in place before the judge’s order was “theoretical” because “the payment system that reimburses partners for expenses they incur is offline,” said Sarah Charles, former head of USAID’s Bureau of Humanitarian Assistance, which oversaw the Food for Peace program. Some relief agencies are still owed for services rendered in December and January, she added. At a contentious meeting at the State Department, the Trump appointee tasked with overseeing USAID — or what is left of it — had assured aid workers and congressional staff that aid payments would resume early next week. But Peter Marocco also said that a department review of the agency’s remaining projects was underway and that those that do not “give the president real influence” will be cut, according to a readout of the event obtained by The Washington Post. A department spokesman did not respond to a request for comment. Complicating the administration’s narrative is a growing tide of Republican lawmakers and former officials who say it’s not quite accurate. Andrew Natsios, who served as USAID administrator during the George W. Bush administration, told lawmakers this week that even those relief organizations already granted waivers haven’t been able to “issue checks” and keep working because of the shutdown of USAID’s payment system. That includes Christian humanitarian groups, which receive $1 billion a year, Natsios said at a House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing Thursday. The session was meant to highlight what Trump and his allies say is USAID’s wasteful spending but instead underscored concerns about the flow of critical assistance, as two of the three expert witnesses warned of dire consequences for U.S. interests and national security if the aid did not resume soon. Sen. Jerry Moran (R-Kansas), who has urged Secretary of State Marco Rubio to “quickly ship and distribute” the American-grown food assistance, is among those questioning what’s happening on the ground. Moran said the State Department last weekend had notified participating groups that they could restart operations. He is skeptical that there has been much impact so far. “My impression is that waivers were granted, but then it doesn’t seem like it was making a significant difference,” he told The Post. He is working with Rep. Tracey Mann (R), a fellow Kansan, and other lawmakers to protect Food for Peace by moving it to the U.S. Department of Agriculture as “part of an ongoing effort to save money and increase efficiency,” Moran said in a statement. That proposal has gained widespread support from agricultural groups. Founded in Kansas, Food for Peace was signed into law in 1954 by President Dwight D. Eisenhower. It has long been championed by the state’s leaders, including former senator Robert J. Dole, and has helped more than 4 billion people in over 150 countries since its inception. The program is a source of pride for farmers. But it has been criticized over the years for various issues, including the potential to undermine local agriculture in recipient countries and exacerbate conflicts in war-torn areas, according to Chris Edwards of the libertarian Cato Institute. Even if the lawmakers prevail, the program’s ultimate survival is not guaranteed. Nick Levendofsky, executive director of the Kansas Farmers Union, pointed to the USDA’s new secretary. Brooke Rollins, former head of a conservative Texas think tank, was confirmed Thursday. “What happens if she goes into this office cleaning house?” Levendofsky asked. “And what about when Elon Musk comes over to USDA? Anything is to be expected at this point.” Kansas is the country’s biggest grower of sorghum, and millions of bushels of the high-protein grain are backed up in warehouses across the state. Kim Barnes, chief financial officer of the Pawnee County Cooperative Association, a grain trader in central Kansas, said he’s storing more than 1.3 million bushels of sorghum because of a market downturn over the last year — a situation that will only worsen with USAID cutbacks. It’s a shame, he said, adding: “There are still countries that need it.” On Thursday, a different federal judge extended a block on the Trump administration’s plan to place thousands of USAID employees on leave. But with thousands of contractors already fired, the agency’s Bureau for Humanitarian Assistance could ultimately lose more than 90 percent of its workforce, Martin, the inspector general, wrote. That outcome exacerbates concerns about whether any existing staff can work with locals on the ground to distribute the commodities, he added. The temporary gap in supplies has been “devastating” some countries, said Paul Spiegel, director of the Johns Hopkins Center for Humanitarian Health and former chief of public health in the Office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. “There has already been much damage done that will be difficult to undo,” Spiegel said Friday. “The administration has not always done what they said they would do providing exceptions for humanitarian response, so the question remains: Will they allow funds to go out, or will they simply slow it down and the pain and suffering of all these vulnerable people around the globe will continue?” Duaa Tarig, who worked as an art curator in Sudan before war broke out, said she personally knew three people who recently died of malnutrition in her Khartoum neighborhood. The pattern is familiar. During a 10-day period last year, many died when soup kitchens in the city were forced to shutter for lack of funding, she recounted. Weakened by starvation, individuals succumbed quickly to malaria or dengue fever. With USAID funding curtailed, more than 80 percent of those soup kitchens have closed again, she said. Many of those remaining open are unable to afford the lentils they usually buy and are scraping together vegetable soups. “Everyone, including myself, have lost a lot of weight. Some have lost more than half their body weight. I see the faces of people I used to know and I can’t recognize them — they are just bone and skin,” she said. Houreld reported from Nairobi. Alice Crites contributed to this report.

inputs.headline: DOGE rips through Education Department, cutting contracts, staff and grants
inputs.content: The notices popped into email boxes all over the country Monday afternoon, notifying researchers who collect, analyze and study data on the American education system that their contracts were terminated, effective immediately. No reason was given. The nixed contracts support the Institute for Education Sciences at the Education Department, known as IES, and inside the agency, staff questioned whether the cuts were legal, much less justified. But the decisions were not made by the institute’s leaders or education experts. Rather, the canceled contracts were all on a list drawn up by a U.S. DOGE Service team that is working to unravel the Education Department, stripping the agency of staff, terminating contracts and — soon — canceling program grants, according to people familiar with DOGE activity who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of losing their jobs. “We’re completely crippled,” said one IES employee. “It really prevents us from serving the mission we thought we were carrying out.” President Donald Trump has made clear he wants the Education Department shuttered. Absent congressional action to do that, his administration is at work dismantling it on its own. On Wednesday, at least 50 recently hired employees who were on probation were abruptly dismissed without cause across the department, according to union leaders. Staff have been warned that layoffs are coming. And managers inside the agency have been instructed to identify workers who can be converted to a new job status that would strip them of some worker protections, according to a person with direct knowledge of the order. In addition, DOGE caused about 100 Education Department employees to be put on administrative leave for their mostly tangential connections to diversity, equity and inclusion programs, based on Trump’s executive order to rid the federal government of DEI offices and initiatives. And in an executive order Tuesday, Trump instructed departments heads across the government to hire no more than one employee for every four employees who depart, and to plan for mass layoffs. “The inmates are running the asylum, and the goal is chaos and the goal is destruction,” Arne Duncan, who served as education secretary in the Obama administration, said in an interview. “We’ve never seen anything like this in our lifetime.” On Friday, the department announced another round of cancellations: $336 million in canceled contracts for Regional Educational Laboratories, which help states apply evidence-based practices to teaching and that have been praised by the former Tennessee schools chief who Trump nominated as deputy secretary of education. The cancellation of contracts began at IES, but is expected to extend to other parts of the department. A department spokeswoman, Madi Biedermann, said earlier this week that 89 contracts worth nearly $900 million had been canceled at IES — not counting the new crop canceled on Friday. Other officials said the total number was 167 or 169. It’s not clear what accounted for the discrepancy. IES has a small full-time staff; most of its work is contracted out. It’s also not clear whether the savings are as deep as the department said. Nat Malkus, a senior fellow at the conservative think tank American Enterprise Institute, pulled data on the canceled contracts that suggested DOGE overstated the cost of some of them. He also found that, in many cases, contractors are already several years into their agreements, so a lot of the money has been spent already. His preliminary calculations show that the actual savings may be half as much as DOGE claims, or less. Malkus’s concern is that agreements were canceled without careful consideration, and for less of a benefit than advertised. “There’s a lot of bloat in IES. There’s a lot of problems to be solved,” he said. “These are problems you solve with a scalpel and maybe a hatchet, but not a bulldozer.” ‘Complete confusion’ The “bulldozer” arrived at IES on Monday, when a young representative of DOGE delivered the list of contracts to be terminated to the department’s acting director. Soon after, a flurry of emergency meetings began, first with managers and then with rank-and-file employees, announcing that the contracts were being canceled, effective immediately. There were no reasons given for the cuts, attendees said, except that DOGE wanted them. The mood was somber, with some holding back tears, staffers said. Confused IES employees asked repeatedly about the legality of DOGE’s actions, but they didn’t get an answer. Meantime, on the outside, texts, emails and calls were bouncing among researchers and contractors as word spread of canceled contracts. The feeling was utter shock and “complete confusion,” said Rachel Dinkes, president and CEO of Knowledge Alliance, a coalition of education research groups. Inside and outside the department, those close to IES research said they were unsettled by the youth and inexperience of DOGE representatives recommending the cancellations, as well as what seemed to be a lack of understanding of the complex, interdependent ecosystem of contracts maintained by IES. For instance, one canceled contract was for work on the Common Core of Data, the primary database of all K-12 schools in the United States. It includes data on enrollment, demographics and other information about students and teachers, and is used by researchers, government agencies and others for a wide range of reasons. It is, said Dinkes, the “backbone” of knowledge about American education and needed for virtually any effort to compare and analyze schools. Contracts for the National Assessment of Educational Progress, or NAEP, exams were not canceled. But Dinkes and others said that NAEP relies on the Common Core of Data when it creates the sample of schools to administer tests. So running the testing program, sometimes called the Nation’s Report Card, will be harder without the Common Core of Data, she said. In another example, DOGE killed a contract for interpreting data IES collects from colleges and universities tracking enrollment and financial aid. The raw data will still be gathered, but the studies that made sense of it for the public are gone. That will make it harder to understand how students are using financial aid, staffers said, and to identify barriers to higher education. “Sure, you have the raw data that scientists can fiddle with, but the necessary step of digesting that in ways that answer questions, it’s gone,” a staffer said. “Now you need a PhD to make any sense of it.” DOGE also canceled contracts IES maintained to publish practice guides for students and schools on topics including how to prepare for college, how to succeed in high school, how to become literate in STEM — and, for educators, how to solve attendance problems. The guides were the most popular product IES publishes, staffers said. In other cases, contracts were for programs that are designed to test the most effective way to solve a problem within the education system. For instance, one contractor was running a study looking at how best to accelerate math learning, Dinkes said. She said the study involved giving half of a group of students one type of instruction and the other half another. The goal was to see which teaching method produced better math results. But the experiment was abruptly terminated this week when the contract was canceled, she said, and the students are no longer getting either of the math interventions. Before the cuts, some employees tried to lay out these complexities for DOGE representatives, a staffer said. Some contracts were expendable, they suggested, but others were not. But the employees were unable to sway DOGE team. “They’ve effectively dismantled us,” said one staffer. “We’re completely crippled,” said another. In addition, many of the canceled contracts were nearing the end of multiyear projects, so terminating them meant time, effort and money already expended may go to waste. “Canceling them now yields the taxpayers no return on their investment,” said a statement from American Institutes for Research, which had 15 IES contracts worth more than $180 million, according to DOGE’s list, which was obtained by The Washington Post. “This is an incredible waste of taxpayer dollars.” Biedermann, the department spokeswoman, said the contracts were costing more than they were worth. But she said she didn’t know how or why DOGE reached that conclusion. “The significant amount of money as compared to the outcomes generated for students is not commensurate,” she said. Asked how DOGE workers have the requisite expertise to make these determinations, she said, “The entire goal of DOGE is to cut waste, and they have been trained to identify that.” Contracts that can be justified or that are congressionally mandated will be rebid, which can be a lengthy process, officials said. The cancellations hung over the confirmation hearing Thursday for Linda McMahon, Trump’s nominee for Education secretary, with several Democrat senators pressing her on what was going on inside the agency. Sen. Edward J. Markey (D-Massachusetts) said DOGE rightfully stands for the “Department of Gutting Education.” “We know that’s just a down payment to gut the education of every public school student in America,” he said. “First they announce the cuts. Then they go to find where it is. So it’s all backwards.” Grants on the chopping block Staff at the Education Department are now bracing for the next round of cuts, they said, including more grant cancellations. Most of the money that Education sends to schools is distributed by a formula, but more than $7 billion is given through competitive grant programs, such as one that pays for after school programs and another that supports charter schools. Last week, staffers were directed to review all grants that have “illegal DEI in them,” another employee said. On Monday, a DOGE account on X said that it had terminated 29 “DEI training grants” at the Education Department totaling $101 million. Also on Monday, DOGE was given access to scour a database detailing all the department’s grants, said one person with knowledge of the situation, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe private proceedings. “Grants will be [canceled] this week or early next,” the person predicted. Then, on Friday, the department announced it was terminating $33 million in grants for Equity Assistance Centers, a program created to support school desegregation but that the department said supports “divisive training.” The DOGE team has also gained access to sensitive department data, including the personal information of millions of borrowers who’ve taken out federal student loans. That’s led to a 30-fold increase in complaints to a privacy office at the department, according to a person familiar with the situation. Duncan, the former education secretary, said DOGE workers have no qualifications and no legal right to access Americans’ personal data. More important, he said, they have the wrong goals. “All this sound and noise and drama and not one word about helping more kids learn to read,” he said. “Not even a mention.”

inputs.headline: HHS in process of firing 5,200 workers, according to internal memo
inputs.content: In an extraordinary move, the Department of Health and Human Services is in the process of firing about 5,200 health workers, part of a government-wide purging of new employees who remain on probationary status, according to an internal memo obtained by The Washington Post. The terminations come one day after Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was sworn in as secretary of the sprawling agency, which oversees the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other agencies. Employees across the department are receiving information sporadically about the firings as the Trump administration takes aggressive measures to impose its policies on the federal bureaucracy. At the CDC, 1,269 staffers who had been on a probationary list will be terminated, according to three federal health officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity due to fear of retribution. All were supposed to receive emails by 4 p.m. That would represent close to 10 percent of the Atlanta-based agency. At NIH, employees were informed that there will be exceptions made for some probationary workers, but details have not been announced. “HHS is following the Administration’s guidance and taking action to support the President’s broader efforts to restructure and streamline the federal government. This is to ensure that HHS better serves the American people at the highest and most efficient standard,” HHS spokesperson Andrew G. Nixon said in an email when asked to comment on the firings.

inputs.headline: Trump plans to further restrict undocumented immigrants from public benefits
inputs.content: President Donald Trump plans to sign an executive order Wednesday evening aimed at restricting undocumented immigrants’ access to financial benefits from federally funded programs, though they already are generally ineligible for most federal public benefits. White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt confirmed Trump’s plans to sign the executive order on X, reposting a report from Fox News reporter Bill Melugin that said the order “will direct every federal agency & department to identify all federally funded programs currently providing any financial benefits to illegal aliens, and ‘take corrective action.’” The action, according to Melugin’s reporting, may be designed to target immigrants who are granted humanitarian parole by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. Along with lawful permanent residents, refugees, people granted asylum and victims of abuse or trafficking, people with parole have access to additional benefits, but are still excluded in many cases, according to the National Immigration Law Center. Some of the benefits available to people regardless of immigration status include emergency disaster assistance, school breakfast and lunch programs and certain public health programs, according to the NILC.

inputs.headline: Trump administration seeking access to database of immigrant minors
inputs.content: The Trump administration is seeking to grant U.S. immigration officers access to a database that contains information on hundreds of thousands of immigrant teens and children who crossed into the United States without their parents, White House border czar Tom Homan told The Washington Post in an interview Friday. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Judge denies temporary ban on DOGE access to private data
inputs.content: A federal judge on Friday denied a request to temporarily ban employees working with the U.S. DOGE Service from accessing closely guarded systems inside the federal government that contain tax returns, Social Security numbers and reams of private data for millions of Americans. But another federal court’s temporary ban remains in place for now. The lawsuit filed in the Eastern District of Virginia by the nonprofit Electronic Privacy Information Center and an anonymous federal worker is one of several seeking to block DOGE, which stands for Department of Government Efficiency, from getting ahold of records kept by the Treasury’s Bureau of the Fiscal Service, which processes about $6 trillion a year in electronic payments to households, businesses and other recipients — and keeps vast stores of data on “virtually every single person in the country,” according to the plaintiffs. Attorneys also asked the judge to block DOGE from accessing records maintained by the U.S. Office of Personnel Management (OPM), which detail the Social Security numbers, birth dates, salaries, home addresses and disciplinary histories of all federal workers and personal information for millions of applicants seeking government jobs. DOGE’s flurry of moves in the first month of the new presidential administration have sparked dozens of lawsuits across the country. In a written opinion Friday, U.S. District Judge Rossie D. Alston Jr. said the nonprofit and the federal worker seeking a preliminary injunction had “not provided concrete evidence that Defendants are actively misusing or even attempting to misuse their sensitive data.” A federal court in Manhattan already had imposed a temporary ban on DOGE access to Americans’ private data held by the Treasury, and other requests for temporary bans are pending before a federal judge in D.C. Alston was appointed by President Donald Trump during his first term. “Plaintiffs’ fears of future harm are much too speculative and would require the Court to make several leaps in reasoning in order to warrant injunctive relief,” Alston wrote. John L. Davisson, director of litigation for the Electronic Privacy Information Center, said at a hearing Friday that exposing millions of Americans’ private financial data in a “historically large and consequential breach” violated several federal laws and the Fifth Amendment, and could leave the United States more vulnerable to malign actors. In one of his first executive orders last month, Trump charged DOGE and its de facto leader, billionaire Elon Musk, with modernizing government agencies and reviewing their functions. Justice Department attorneys said in a legal filing that the groups suing over DOGE’s moves were “seeking unprecedented judicial micromanagement of the Executive Branch’s ability to share government data with its own employees.” Jonathan Lucier, an assistant U.S. attorney in Virginia, said at a court hearing Friday that the employees in question were all hired by Treasury and OPM or detailed to those agencies. Granting data access to in-house employees carrying out a presidential initiative “cannot be illegal,” Lucier argued. Tom Krause, a tech company chief executive who briefly worked for DOGE, is now a senior Treasury adviser and the only liaison to the group. Justice Department attorneys said in court papers that he has never been given “direct access” to the Bureau of the Fiscal Service payment system, only “over-the-shoulder” access “to review activity others performed in the system or data others accessed from the system.” But Justice Department attorneys acknowledged in a footnote that another employee who began working at DOGE and was then hired by Treasury, Marko Elez, did have access to the closely guarded payment system — which includes details of highly classified programs — until he resigned Feb. 6. He was found to have made racist statements on social media. Musk said he would rehire Elez, who now works at the Social Security Administration, according to Bloomberg News. In response to a lawsuit filed by 19 states, another federal court barred Krause from accessing Americans’ personal or financial information pending further legal proceedings. U.S. District Judge Paul A. Engelmayer in Manhattan found that the states would face irreparable harm without the temporary ban “because of the risk that the new policy presents of the disclosure of sensitive and confidential information and the heightened risk that the systems in question will be more vulnerable than before to hacking.” Another federal judge in Manhattan issued a preliminary injunction in that case Friday, prohibiting DOGE from accessing the Treasury data while the states’ lawsuit is pending. U.S. District Judge Jeannette A. Vargas said she could lift the ban if the Trump administration can show it is taking steps to safeguard the public’s most sensitive data.

inputs.headline: President Donald Trump just signed executive orders declaring a “national energy emergency” and “unleashing” domestic fossil...
inputs.content: President Donald Trump just signed executive orders declaring a “national energy emergency” and “unleashing” domestic fossil fuel production. It was not immediately clear what government actions the energy emergency would entail, although Trump allies have suggested the order could allow the administration to quickly approve pipelines and other fossil fuel infrastructure.

inputs.headline: Judge adds one-week pause on Trump plan to put 2,100 USAID workers on leave
inputs.content: A federal judge on Thursday extended for seven days his temporary restraining order on the Trump administration’s move to place about 2,100 employees from the U.S. Agency for International Development on paid leave, delaying any action while the judge weighs whether to order a longer pause. Two labor unions representing USAID employees sued the Trump administration last week, saying the sudden halt to funding not only upended overseas aid programs but endangered some employees’ lives in various countries. U.S. District Judge Carl J. Nichols, a Trump appointee, first entered a restraining order last week stopping the plan. On Thursday, he told Justice Department employees to submit to him by Friday the steps it was taking to ensure overseas employees’ safety and to indicate whether it would cover employees’ other benefits, such as school or car payments, while they are on leave. Nichols had set his original restraining order to expire at 11:59 p.m. Friday. He extended all the deadlines in the order by one week, while he drafts an opinion on whether to enjoin the spending shutdowns throughout the litigation. He amended the order to ban involuntary evacuations of USAID workers overseas, but not voluntary ones. Lawyers on both sides were not fully clear last week how many USAID workers were affected. The government said in an affidavit that 2,140 employees had been placed on paid leave as of Feb. 7, replacing the 2,700 figure used in last week’s hearing. The government said 98 percent of those placed on leave were stationed in the United States. The unions said Thursday USAID employs about 4,700 people, and about 1,400 live abroad. The Trump administration has argued that it was merely pausing USAID spending while it examines whether the agency is pursuing Trump’s agenda, and that some top aides were ousted for refusing directions to immediately stop funding. The employees’ union said the pause has already damaged aid programs around the world and possibly placed employees in danger by not paying for their cellphones, internet or other security measures. The suit marks the first major legal challenge to the push by President Donald Trump and his allies, led by billionaire Elon Musk and his U.S. DOGE Service, or Department of Government Efficiency, targeting foreign aid programs and USAID staff as part of their campaign to reshape the federal government. The lawsuit is one of several legal challenges mounted by Trump opponents seeking to slow or halt the administration’s barrage of actions to curtail spending, pare back the administrative state, eradicate diversity initiatives and more. The judge’s extension comes as the Trump administration grows increasingly defensive of the chaos caused by the halt in aid projects around the world. On Thursday, the Trump administration sent an internal memo to USAID employees threatening to fire them if they communicated with the press about continued disruptions to foreign aid despite Secretary of State Marco Rubio’s issuing an exemption for “lifesaving humanitarian assistance” last month. “﻿The purpose of this memo is to correct a false narrative in the press, and provide clarity for staff on external communications,” wrote USAID official Mark Lloyd to staff in a memo obtained by The Washington Post. Rubio’s exemption “has continued uninterrupted and was never paused,” Lloyd added. “Unauthorized engagement externally with the press or others is subject to discipline, including dismissal.” Leading aid groups say even when they’ve obtained exemptions, they cannot continue their work because Rubio’s “stop work” order has effectively shut down payment systems required to draw down funds. That has resulted in thousands of aid workers and USAID contractors being furloughed, disrupting projects from Asia to Africa to Latin America. USAID and the State Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the matter. In another move this week, the White House fired the inspector general for USAID on Tuesday after he released a blistering report saying $489 million in food assistance was at risk of spoilage or potential diversion because of the funding freeze and work stoppage. The Trump administration is “engaged in a wholesale and rapid campaign to dissolve the USAID in its entirety,” said attorney Karla Gilbride, representing both the American Foreign Service Association and the American Federation of Government Employees. “That campaign has begun with the freezing of all funding on USAID projects.” Nichols immediately interjected, saying, “As I understand it, all funding on all projects is not frozen.” Gilbride said the government’s claims do “not match the reality on the ground,” in which bills are not being paid and employees are operating in an information vacuum as USAID leadership in Washington is upended. “It is not consistent with the declaration that this is just a ‘pencils down’ pause. Which is what a 90-day review suggested.” The unions have argued that USAID is a body created by Congress, and a law passed last year requires the president to notify and consult Congress if it intends to “reorganize or redesign, eliminate, consolidate or downsize any agency,” Gilbride said. “It’s necessary that the court impose the injunction and extend the temporary order so that the situation doesn’t get worse,” Gilbride said. With a preliminary injunction, Nichols would not be making a final judgment on whether the USAID moves are legal. For now, he must decide whether irreparable harm will be caused if he doesn’t issue the injunction while also considering the likelihood of whether the employees will prevail on the larger question. Nichols seemed particularly concerned by a “clearly harrowing situation” in Democratic Republic of Congo, where USAID staff in Kinshasa had to evacuate due to civil unrest there but couldn’t obtain any funds from Washington to do so, and wound up crossing the Congo River in small boats, leaving their homes and belongings behind. Justice Department attorney Eric Hamilton said the Trump administration was “committed to every USAID employee’s security, and everyone will be kept safe.” Hamilton said the Justice Department believes Trump acted within his authority under Article II of the Constitution, and “Eight foreign aid statutes recognize the need for presidential direction in this space. We think it’s consistent with all of those authorities, that the president when he comes into office, on the first day to take brief stock to see that foreign aid is only let out consistent with his policy.” Hamilton added: “We don’t think a reorganization has happened. It’s a 90-day pause.” But he noted Rubio did send a letter to Congress on Feb. 3 notifying them of the move. “That notice checks the box,” Hamilton said of the requirement for the president to consult with Congress before remaking an agency. “We think the specifics of that consultation would be a political question.” Nichols raised the issue of whether the employees’ complaints of mistreatment should be heard by a civil service board, such as the Merit Systems Protection Board, rather than a court. Harrison agreed. “The only thing that’s changing is whether they’re doing work and having access to systems,” Harrison said. “This makes this very much a personnel dispute, not appropriate for federal district court.” Gilbride responded that going through civil service appeals can “take years to reach a conclusion. By the time the MSPB process goes through, many years may have passed and there will no longer be a USAID for individuals to return to. … The unions that are in this case are not seeking damages or back pay on behalf of their members. What they’re seeking is that USAID not be unconstitutionally dissolved.” The extension comes as former U.S. officials who served in both Democratic and Republican administrations have become increasingly vocal about the ramifications of USAID’s dismantling. On Wednesday, more than 200 former officials wrote a letter to leaders of the House and Senate saying “the human suffering that these cutoffs have caused is catastrophic and heartbreaking.” “In Kenya, Syria, Lebanon and elsewhere, aid to survivors of torture was stopped in its tracks,” said the officials, who include Michael Hayden, who headed the National Security Agency during the Bush administration; former CIA officer Bruce Riedel; former Middle East adviser Aaron David Miller; former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch; and others. “Children and adult victims of war and terror who have relied on the United States have been left without care. And in poorer countries around the world, thousands of women and girls will die in the next 90 days due to complications of childbirth that might otherwise have been avoided through interventions funded by Congress and administered by USAID,” they wrote in the letter, obtained by The Post.

inputs.headline: More than 40,000 workers said to accept deferred resignation offer
inputs.content: More than 40,000 people have accepted the Trump administration’s deferred resignation offer, according to a person familiar with the figures who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly. A day before the offer expires, the total is double what was first reported by Axios earlier this week but still less than the goal advertised by Elon Musk, the billionaire spearheading President Donald Trump’s vision for a smaller and more loyal workforce. Musk shared a post on X, his social media platform, that claimed that between 5 and 10 percent of employees eligible for the order would take it. Asked about the total, which is less than 2 percent of the civilian workforce of 2.3 million, an official with the Office of Personnel Management said the number of employees who have accepted the offer “is growing.”

inputs.headline: Trump set to pull funding from schools based on race, gender teaching
inputs.content: The White House is preparing to issue a trio of executive orders on education, including one directing the Education Department to withhold federal funding from any school that teaches about “radical gender ideology” or “critical race theory,” officials said Wednesday. The order instructs the secretary of education to present a strategy to achieve this within 90 days, according to a summary. A second order promotes school choice options, including an attempt to help states use federal funding for private-school voucher programs. The third order seeks to combat antisemitism in schools. For years, Republicans including President Donald Trump have attacked schools for teaching a basket of ideas about systemic racism labeled critical race theory. Trump has also attacked schools for policies and lessons that recognize and respect transgender students. Federal law allows the agency to withhold federal funds from any school that discriminates based on race. Trump and his allies argue that lessons about systemic racism amount to discrimination, because they presume certain things about people based on race, such as that White Americans enjoy certain privileges based on their race. They say that giving rights to transgender students, especially transgender girls and women, discriminates against cisgender girls and women by forcing them to share spaces and sports teams. The order also reinstates the 1776 Commission, which Trump created just a week before the 2020 presidential election to promote “patriotic education.” The commission wrote a report that was published in the final days of his first term. The report came under heavy fire from historians as a distortion of American history, and President Joe Biden disbanded the panel as one of his first acts. As a candidate, Trump promised to reinstate the commission if reelected. Cleve R. Wootson Jr. contributed to this report.

inputs.headline: Vaccine safety panel long criticized by RFK Jr. told to postpone meeting
inputs.content: The Trump administration has directed the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to indefinitely postpone a public meeting of its vaccine advisory panel, a key forum for the nation’s discussion of information about vaccine safety and effectiveness. The decision came Thursday from officials at the Department of Health and Human Services, CDC’s parent agency, led by anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has long criticized the panel and the CDC. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Judge says Trump officials have not complied with order to restart foreign aid
inputs.content:
A federal judge in D.C. on Thursday told the Trump administration it had failed to comply with his order to restart billions in foreign aid but stopped short of holding officials in contempt of court as plaintiffs in a pair of lawsuits had asked.
Earlier this month, U.S. District Court Judge Amir H. Ali issued a temporary restraining order blocking the administration from putting a 90-day pause on foreign assistance. In Thursday’s ruling, he said the order “was clear,” but Trump officials had not followed it.
President Donald Trump placed the aid on hold as one of his first actions after taking office in January, saying the aid did not align with American interests or values.
Health organizations filed suit in response, claiming the Trump administration was endangering the lives of many around the world who relied on the assistance to combat HIV, malaria and tuberculosis. The money also went to other development projects.
After Ali issued his temporary restraining order, or TRO, requiring Trump officials to restart the aid on Feb. 13, the administration said it had authority under other statutes to continue much of the freeze. Ali rejected that idea Thursday.
“The TRO does not permit Defendants to simply search for and invoke new legal authorities as a post-hoc rationalization for the enjoined agency action,” Ali wrote.

inputs.headline: Trump says he will fire Kennedy Center board members, appoint himself chairman
inputs.content: President Donald Trump on Friday announced plans to overhaul the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, writing that he had decided to “immediately terminate multiple individuals from the Board of Trustees,” including chairman David M. Rubenstein, in a post on Truth Social. He added that he plans to install himself as the new chairman of the prominent arts institution. He did not say which board members he plans to terminate. It is unclear whether the president has the power to make such changes. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Arab leaders scramble for alternative to Trump’s Gaza proposal
inputs.content: President Donald Trump’s plan to remove Palestinians from the Gaza Strip and create a real estate “riviera” on the eastern Mediterranean has spurred a regional scramble for an alternative, with Arab leaders working on a proposal that aims to pump billions of dollars in reconstruction money into the enclave, according to people familiar with the planning. Leaders from Jordan, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar met in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, on Friday to thrash out details less than three weeks after Trump laid out a plan for the United States to “take over” Gaza and displace the population there, a proposal that has been broadly condemned as tantamount to ethnic cleansing. The emerging Arab plan would call for Palestinian technocrats to govern Gaza and the provision of substantial funds to rebuild the shattered enclave, where the vast majority of the population of 2 million has been left homeless, according to five people with knowledge of the discussions. And while details of the plan are still being hashed out, they say there is resounding unanimity on one issue: Palestinians should not be displaced. “The Trump proposal is so outlandish and offensive to many in the Middle East that certainly it’s a nonstarter. It’s a hot mess,” said Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Connecticut), who has discussed plans with regional leaders including Jordan’s King Abdullah II, whom Blumenthal met in the Jordanian Red Sea resort of Aqaba this week. “The Arab plan will seek to present a realistic proposal for reconstruction in Gaza without forced evacuation and without a United States takeover,” Blumenthal said in a telephone interview. The broad strokes of the Arab plan — hoped to be finalized ahead of an emergency summit with representatives of the broader 22-member Arab League on March 4 — are “becoming clearer,” Blumenthal said. But significant hurdles remain, including reaching Arab consensus and obtaining U.S. and Israeli buy-in, he added. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said that Israel is “committed” to Trump’s plan and described it as a “bold vision” for Gaza. The proposal has also received rapturous approval from the country’s far-right politicians, who have pushed for Israeli settlements in Gaza and the enclave’s annexation. But Arab states are hoping to garner backing for their plan with their checkbooks. A new assessment by the United Nations estimates that it could cost $50 billion to rebuild Gaza after the devastation caused by 15 months of war. The exact figure to be put forward is “still up for review,” but the proposal is likely to include a headline number, said Emirati academic Abdulkhaleq Abdulla, a visiting fellow at Harvard University. “The number is important because they know the president of the United States is transactional, he likes numbers, and they think he might be swayed when he sees these billions of dollars,” including construction opportunities for U.S. companies, he said. Egyptian Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly said this week that regional construction firms, including those in Egypt, have the capacity to build 300,000 housing units over a three-year period. Other proposals being considered appear aimed at keeping Trump’s interest in investment at the heart of Gaza’s future. One, from the Al Habtoor Group, an Emirati conglomerate, outlines a phased approach that would establish security in the territory and transition emergency housing into redevelopment over 18 months. Arab countries know they hold leverage by being “the ATMs” for reconstruction, said Brian Katulis, a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute. However, the “clash of worldviews,” between Israel and Trump on one side and the region on the other, remains a major sticking point, he said. During his trip to Washington this month, Netanyahu looked on smiling as Trump outlined his plans for a U.S. “takeover” of Gaza. “The big impediment is if the whole exercise will be accepted by Trump, and certainly big questions over whether it will be accepted by the current Israeli government,” Katulis said of the Arab plan. Phase one of the Arab plan envisages reconstruction in areas that have not been completely obliterated, but Arab leaders are willing to open their wallets only if other political and security elements of a plan are put in place, said Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Maryland), who has recently met with ministers from Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Jordan to discuss evolving plans. “It’s a delicate balancing act because all these three pieces need to converge,” he said. The technocratic committee envisioned for Gaza under the Arab plan would not include Hamas, the ruler of Gaza for almost two decades and architect of the Oct. 7, 2023, attack on Israel. “The two main driving principles on the governance side is that Hamas will have no governing role in Gaza, and also that it creates a political unity with the West Bank,” said Van Hollen, adding that Arab states want the Palestinian Authority, the governing entity in the West Bank, to have some degree of sign-off on the structure. Arab leaders, like previous U.S. administrations, have long advocated a clear path to a two-state solution, which Netanyahu has repeatedly opposed, along with any rule by the Palestinian Authority in Gaza. “Squaring that circle is a big challenge at this point,” Van Hollen said. Two officials briefed on the plans, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive proposals that are still in flux, emphasized that the technocratic government is intended to be a “temporary” body to oversee rebuilding and would remain in place only until elections could be held. While many officials in Abu Dhabi, the UAE capital, and in Riyadh remain frustrated that they were not informed before Trump floated the Gaza displacement plan, they also acknowledge that the U.S. leader’s approach has succeeded in motivating the Arab states to act, according to the officials. “Trump scrambled the table, and it forced other people to start doing some of the heavy lifting,” said one individual familiar with the thinking of the regional leadership. Others in the region draw parallels to Trump’s comments on Ukraine that spurred emergency meetings of leaders in Europe. But Van Hollen said he also fears that Trump’s plan has set back the chances of making a deal. “In addition to being outrageous on its face, it’s further emboldened the far right and made it more difficult to achieve an overall settlement,” he said. Hamas’s objections are another potential spoiler to any plan, as is the thorny question of who will provide security in Gaza. Hamas still holds weapons stockpiles, while the security vacuum has led to a rise in criminal gangs. “There is still a very challenging and complicated road ahead, even if Arab leaders present a realistic plan,” said Blumenthal, adding that Abdullah has been “very clear-eyed and realistic” in his thinking. But while the gaps remain wide, both Trump and Netanyahu want a normalization deal between Saudi Arabia and Israel, and also to maintain a regional coalition against Iran as Israel mulls strikes against Tehran’s nuclear program. “There is a golden opportunity for Israel to integrate with the region and recognize its wildest dreams,” said Katulis. While Trump’s initial proposal to empty Gaza of its inhabitants sparked anger in Saudi Arabia, the close ties between the two powers were on full display this week. Trump made an appearance at a Saudi investment summit in Miami after tapping Riyadh to host talks to end the war in Ukraine. The coverage in Saudi media was glowing. Saudi Arabia “has achieved success on all fronts,” proclaimed a column in Asharq al-Awsat by Tariq Alhomayed, the newspaper’s former editor. Speaking at the summit in Miami on Thursday, Steve Witkoff, Trump’s special envoy to the Middle East, addressed Gaza and appeared to dial back elements of the president’s plan that had caused alarm, saying some of Trump’s comments had been misconstrued. The level of destruction is so great, a five-year development plan “is not physically possible,” he said. “That doesn’t mean we are on an eviction plan,” he said. “It means the president wants to shake up everybody’s thinking.” Witkoff said Arab leaders are now considering new solutions for rebuilding Gaza, ideas that “people would have never considered, and I think that’s a good thing.” Abigail Hauslohner in Washington contributed to this report.

inputs.headline: Trump shuts off access to asylum, plans to send 10,000 troops to border
inputs.content: President Donald Trump is preparing to send 10,000 troops to the southern border, and Border Patrol agents have been directed to deny entry to asylum seekers if they “traveled through a country with communicable disease,” according to a U.S. Customs and Border Protection briefing document obtained by The Washington Post. The order does not list any specific disease, essentially closing the border to anyone attempting to exercise the right to seek humanitarian refuge under U.S. law. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Trump appoints loyalists to Kennedy Center board
inputs.content: President Donald Trump was officially elected chair of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Wednesday, installing a new board of trustees as he furthers his executive authority to remake one of the nation’s premier cultural institutions. The Kennedy Center’s new board is composed of Trump loyalists, including White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles, White House Deputy Chief of Staff Dan Scavino, second lady Usha Vance, former transportation secretary Elaine Chao and Trump himself, according to its website. “It is a Great Honor to be Chairman of The Kennedy Center, especially with this amazing Board of Trustees. We will make The Kennedy Center a very special and exciting place!” Trump posted on Truth Social, noting he was voted in as chairman unanimously. Trump’s recasting of the Kennedy Center board breaks from tradition. The arts venue has typically been led by a bipartisan board and evenly split between Democratic and Republican appointees to ensure diverse programming. On Monday on Truth Social, Trump also named former acting director of national intelligence Richard Grenell, who is serving as an envoy for special missions, as the interim executive director of the Kennedy Center.

inputs.headline: President Donald Trump signed an executive order Monday creating the “Department of Government Efficiency” led by...
inputs.content:
President Donald Trump signed an executive order Monday creating the “Department of Government Efficiency” led by his billionaire adviser and donor Elon Musk. The executive order was expected to create a DOGE office within the White House, although Trump had initially said the panel would exist outside the government.
Musk will have an office in the White House with about 20 people, Trump said Monday. Trump said DOGE’s White House office would help ensure the executive actions would get implemented.

inputs.headline: HUD moves to cancel $1.1 billion in already-awarded housing upgrades
inputs.content:
The Department of Housing and Urban Development, acting on a directive from DOGE, is moving to terminate more than $1.1 billion in loans and grants awarded to improve the energy efficiency and weather resilience of multifamily housing, according to a department official with knowledge of the order.
The termination of the Green and Resilient Retrofit Program puts into jeopardy more than 260 projects across the country, several of which have already begun construction. The projects were expected to create “hundreds, if not thousands of jobs” according to the department official. “It’s unfortunate that they are targeting such an effective program just because it has the word ‘green’ in its name,” the official said.
The department communications office did not respond to questions from The Washington Post. The move is likely to spark legal challenges, as the congressionally authorized funds were already awarded by the department, which is now trying to claw them back.
The program, created through the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, is targeted at upgrading subsidized housing units. It is designed to help building owners and residents lower their utility bills by using less energy, as well as help fund improvements such as fire-resistant roofs and new heating systems that will prolong the life of the units.
“This program helps to rehabilitate affordable apartments, making sure residents have lower utility costs and can survive extreme weather,” said Lowell Ungar, federal policy director for the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy. “You disrupt that and it means higher bills for those who can least afford them and greater risk from storms and heat waves.”

inputs.headline: FAA targeting Verizon contract in favor of Musk’s Starlink, sources say
inputs.content: The Federal Aviation Administration is close to canceling a $2.4 billion contract to overhaul a communications system that serves as the backbone of the nation’s air traffic control system and awarding the work to Elon Musk’s Starlink, according to two people briefed on the plans. The move to cancel a major contract in favor of a venture led by Musk — who is leading President Donald Trump’s disruptive overhaul of the federal government through the U.S. DOGE Service — would represent a significant test of protections against conflicts of interest in government projects. It would be an especially extraordinary step for the typically cautious FAA, whose systems are vital to the safety of millions of air travelers every day. The existing contract was awarded to Verizon in 2023, with the aim of upgrading a platform that different air traffic control facilities and FAA offices use to communicate with one another. Musk has personally taken aim at Verizon on his social media platform X in recent days, saying on Monday: “The Verizon system is not working and so is putting air travelers at serious risk.” Verizon did not respond to a request for comment. Joseph Russo, a Verizon executive vice president, said at an event hosted by Barclays Bank on Tuesday that Starlink’s efforts at FAA might be complementary to Verizon’s. Verizon was offering the “reliability and performance” that the FAA needed, and its system was expected to be operational soon, Russo said. The FAA said in a statement Wednesday that “no decisions have been made” about the Verizon project. A team of employees from SpaceX, Starlink’s parent company, has been working inside the FAA in recent days, charged by the Trump administration with helping modernize the agency’s aging technology. Ted Malaska, one of them, shared a picture on X on Thursday saying he was excited to be working with the FAA, and thanking Musk and Trump for their “vision and focus on safety.” “I challenge anyone to question the honesty and my technical integrity on this matter,” Malaska posted Wednesday. “I am working without biases for the safety of people that fly.” Several of the SpaceX employees now have FAA email addresses, according to two people who have seen the addresses, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of retribution. FAA regulates SpaceX and has alleged that the company has violated safety rules relating to its rocket launches. In a statement Monday, the FAA said it was testing Starlink systems at facilities in New Jersey and Alaska, in hopes of providing more reliable connectivity in remote locations. Elements of the FAA’s deliberations were previously reported by the Associated Press and Bloomberg News. Transportation Secretary Sean P. Duffy said on Fox News this week that the government had been too slow to modernize its technology and that the new administration was ready to move quickly. “We’re going to look at a year, year-and-a-half time frame and do massive upgrades, improve the systems, help air traffic controllers, keep our skies safer,” Duffy said. But the Starlink plan adds to Musk’s existing conflicts of interest at the FAA relating to SpaceX, according to John P. Pelissero, the director of an ethics center at Santa Clara University. Pelissero said it appears that “because of Musk’s current position in DOGE and his closeness to Trump he and his company are getting an advantage and getting a contract.” “Who’s looking out for the public interest here when you get the person who’s cutting budgets and personnel from the FAA, suddenly trying to benefit from still another government contract?” Pelissero said. The Transportation Department, DOGE and SpaceX did not respond to questions on how the process of changing contractors has been handled and whether potential conflicts of interest have been reviewed. Trump has said Musk will not be permitted to participate in decisions that pose a conflict of interest. Verizon was tapped in 2023 to build a system called the FAA Enterprise Network Services Program or FENS, replacing a system that dates to 2002. The contract had a 15-year lifespan, and the system is intended to connect some 4,600 sites, according to the FAA. The agency was scheduled to make a final decision on whether to start paying Verizon for the contract next month, said one of the people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly. Instead, Musk’s team determined the job should go to Starlink, the person said. But the process for unwinding a contract and awarding it to another company is lengthy and has not been followed in this case so far, the person said. Several senior FAA officials have refused to sign paperwork authorizing the switch, according to the person, who has been briefed on the internal deliberations and resulting fallout, so Musk’s team is now seeking help from the acting administrator of the agency, Trump appointee Chris Rocheleau, and Duffy. Outside reviews of the FAA’s technology have repeatedly concluded in recent years that it is woefully out of date and that the agency is too slow to make upgrades. A 2023 safety review pointed to technological problems as one factor that was creating “risk” in the aviation system, a problem the Verizon contract is supposed to help solve. Jessica Tillipman, the associate dean for government and procurement law studies at George Washington University School of Law, said terminating a contract can be expensive, time consuming and could lead to litigation. “When the government terminates a contract it’s not like it shuts off the spigot,” she said. “It’s expensive to wind down a contract. It’s very expensive and it’s complicated.” She said negotiating a settlement can take a year. In awarding a new contract, agencies must comply with the Competition and Contracting Act, which requires competition in government procurements. It does have some exceptions. Among those: national security, public interest or urgency, she said. “But the question is, how is it so urgent when you already had a contractor dealing with it?,” said Tillipman, adding that there are many different guardrails within the federal acquisition system to make sure things are fair, transparent and efficient. “However, in the last few weeks she said many of these guardrails have been tested, which will likely lead to litigation,” she said. Washington Post researcher Aaron Schaffer contributed to this report.

inputs.headline: Trump: Government will sell $5 million ‘gold card’ to wealthy immigrants
inputs.content: President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that the United States will soon sell a $5 million “gold card” to give foreign nationals “green card privileges” and a “route to citizenship.” Trump made the announcement during an executive order signing in the Oval Office, telling reporters, “Wealthy people will be coming into our country by buying this card.” “They’ll be spending a lot of money and paying a lot of taxes and employing a lot of people, and we think it’s going to be extremely successful,” Trump said, claiming that the program — which he said will begin in about two weeks under his executive authority and without the approval of Congress — is “totally legal.” Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told reporters in the Oval Office that the Trump administration will be ending the controversial EB-5 investor visa — sometimes referred to by critics as the “golden visa.” The citizenship pathway created in 1990 requires significant investments in a new business that would create full-time jobs in the United States. Lutnick said the $5 million requirement for the “gold card” would be paid “to the U.S. government” and applicants would require “thorough vetting.” Lutnick suggested the money would be used “to reduce our deficit,” but Trump would not definitively state whether that money would be earmarked specifically for deficit reduction. The president said that if “gold card” holders create jobs within the United States, “they’ll pay full taxes like everybody else.” Trump also said he anticipated that the card would be used by American companies seeking to bring in talent from abroad. When asked whether Russian oligarchs would be eligible for a “gold card,” Trump responded, “Yeah, possibly. I know some Russian oligarchs that are very nice people.”

inputs.headline: Trump says administration looking at sending criminals out of country
inputs.content:
“Numerous countries” have offered to imprison U.S. citizen criminals, President Donald Trump said Tuesday, and “if we have the legal right to do it, I would do it in a heartbeat.”
For “a small fee compared to what we pay” in government-run and private prisons in this country, he said, “we can make deals where we get these animals out of our country.”
He said his administration was examining the legality of such action.
Trump’s comments, made in response to questions from reporters witnessing his signing of new executive orders at the White House, came after Salvadoran President Nayib Bukele said this week that he would imprison U.S. criminals for payment.
“We have hardened criminals, horrible people, you see them pushing people into subways,” Trump said. “We don’t want these people in our country. … These people are never going to be any good.”
If they are sent out of the country, he said, “you would have a lot less crime automatically.”

inputs.headline: Pentagon says ‘identity months’  like Black History Month are ‘dead’
inputs.content: Shortly after President Donald Trump signed a proclamation celebrating National Black History Month on Friday, the Pentagon issued guidance declaring that “identity months” were “dead” within the Defense Department. Trump’s proclamation acknowledged the contribution of several history-making Black Americans, calling upon “public officials, educators, librarians, and all the people of the United States to observe this month with appropriate programs, ceremonies, and activities.” But Friday’s guidance from Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth specifically states that the Pentagon will no longer “use official resources, to include man-hours, to host celebrations or events related to cultural awareness months, including National African American/Black History Month, Women’s History Month, Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month, National Hispanic Heritage Month, National Disability Employment Awareness Month, and National American Indian Heritage Month.” The memo added though that employees, including service members in the military and civilians, could attend such events outside of their work time. “We are proud of our warriors and their history, but we will focus on the character of their service instead of their immutable characteristics,” the memo says.

inputs.headline: U.S., Ukraine near deal to grant mineral rights to Washington
inputs.content: The Trump administration and the Ukrainian government were nearing a deal Friday to hand Ukrainian mineral resources over to the United States in exchange for continued security assistance, a person familiar with the negotiations said, potentially easing President Donald Trump’s days of attacks against the embattled country and its leadership. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Trump to build mass detention camp for deportees at Guantánamo Bay
inputs.content: President Donald Trump said he will order the construction of a mass detention camp that can hold 30,000 deportees at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base, outlining plans Wednesday for the largest U.S. facility of its kind. Speaking at the White House before signing the Laken Riley Act, a bill that is expected to expand the number of immigrant detainees held in U.S. custody for minor property crimes, Trump said the massive camp would “detain the worst criminal illegal aliens threatening the American people” and be “a tough place to get out of.” Read the full story

inputs.headline: Federal judge blocks Trump from slashing NIH funding in 22 states that sued
inputs.content: A federal district judge granted a temporary restraining order Monday that blocks the Trump administration from making drastic cuts to biomedical research funding in 22 states that banded together to sue. Judge Angel Kelley, in federal district court in Massachusetts, ordered the National Institutes of Health not to implement a funding change that the agency had announced Friday night, which would dramatically reduce funding to universities and other research organizations for indirect costs related to research. Read the full story

inputs.headline: New Kennedy Center board elects Trump as chair. Rutter departs as president.
inputs.content: The Kennedy Center board of trustees voted Wednesday afternoon to install President Donald Trump as chairman of the board, cementing the plan Trump announced Friday to overhaul the storied arts institution with him at its helm. In a staff meeting that followed, Deborah Rutter said she was departing as president. On Monday, Trump named former acting director of national intelligence Richard Grenell as the interim executive director of the Kennedy Center in a post on Truth Social. The position plunged leadership at the Kennedy Center into confusion, as the position “executive director” does not exist. Read the full story

inputs.headline: In new order, Trump administration places more USAID staff on leave
inputs.content:
The Trump administration put scores of additional employees of the U.S. Agency for International Development on leave Tuesday, dealing a further blow to the beleaguered aid agency.
In a new letter, Pete Marocco, who was appointed by Secretary of State Marco Rubio as a senior agency official, told affected USAID personnel they were being put on a paid “excused absence” effective immediately.
“During the period that you are on administrative leave you are not to enter USAID premises, access USAID systems, or attempt to use your position or authority with USAID in any way without my prior permission or prior permission of a supervisor in your chain of command,” Marocco said in the letter, copies of which were obtained by The Washington Post.
It was not immediately clear how many employees were affected. One USAID official said the number could be as high as 1,400.
The move is the latest action since Trump’s return to the White House impacting USAID employees, many of whom have been furloughed or forced out of their jobs, and America’s overseas assistance programs, many of which were suspended while the new administration conducts a review of USAID’s activities.
The campaign to overhaul — and potentially abolish — USAID has been led by billionaire Elon Musk, who is advising Trump in his effort to shrink the federal government. Musk has tweeted that USAID “must die.”
Placing officials on administrative leave has hamstrung large parts of USAID just as humanitarian groups around the world seek exemptions to Trump’s 90-day aid freeze. Officials who received the letter were immediately locked out of emails and unable to manage the flood of exemption requests, a bottleneck that aid workers say has prevented life-saving aid projects from restarting across the developing world.
USAID did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
Democrats have vowed to fight any attempt to dismantle the agency, citing its creation in statute. A Democratic Senate aide, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Tuesday’s move to put additional staff on leave was “sweeping in nature.”

inputs.headline: Dept. of Homeland Security wants IRS to help with immigration enforcement
inputs.content: Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem has requested that the Treasury Department provide IRS personnel to assist with immigration enforcement, the Trump administration’s latest effort to expand federal resources to fulfill his campaign pledge to deport more undocumented immigrants. In a Friday memo to Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Noem cited several areas in which U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement needs additional help. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Trump administration orders Pentagon to plan for sweeping budget cuts
inputs.content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered senior leaders at the Pentagon and throughout the U.S. military to develop plans for cutting eight percent from the defense budget in each of the next five years, according to a memo obtained by The Washington Post and officials familiar with the matter — a striking proposal certain to face internal resistance and strident bipartisan opposition in Congress. Hegseth ordered the proposed cuts to be drawn up by Feb. 24, according to the memo, which includes a list of 17 categories that the Trump administration wants exempted. Among them: operations at the southern U.S. border, modernization of nuclear weapons and missile defense, and acquisition of one-way attack drones and other munitions. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Trump threatens to cut U.S. aid to South Africa over land law
