The brief administrative order, which did not address the underlying legal issues, will allow time for a full Supreme Court review. U.S. District Judge Amir H. Ali had given the administration until 11:59 p.m. to fulfill its contractual obligations and restart the payments to organizations whose work in impoverished parts of the world had been stopped since President Donald Trump halted such foreign assistance in late January. Acting solicitor general Sarah M. Harris, the government’s top appellate lawyer, had asked the Supreme Court to block Ali’s order, which she said had “thrown what should be an orderly review by the government into chaos.” The lower-court order, Harris wrote, exceeds the judiciary’s authority. The government is “committed to paying legitimate claims for work that was properly completed,” she added. “What the government cannot do is pay arbitrarily determined demands on an arbitrary timeline of the district court’s choosing.” Roberts gave the global aid organizations challenging the administration’s actions until noon Friday to respond to those assertions. The request to the Supreme Court marked the second time the new administration has asked the justices to intervene after a lower-court judge blocked Trump’s efforts to reshape the federal government. Last week, the high court refused to immediately clear the way for the removal of Hampton Dellinger, the head of an independent watchdog agency, whom Trump tried to fire. Trump issued the wide-ranging pause on foreign aid shortly after his inauguration. His allies quickly began dismantling the U.S. Agency for International Development, the $40 billion arm of the government that assists humanitarian work in more than 100 countries. The moves left millions of people at risk of hunger and illness and thousands of USAID employees without jobs, some stranded in dangerous places around the world. Two groups — the AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition and the Global Health Council — filed suit. On Feb. 13, Ali, a Biden appointee who has been on the bench only since December, issued a temporary restraining order prohibiting the administration from stopping the aid payments. But in the days that followed, advocates alleged in court, administration officials openly defied the order, continued to lay off thousands of staffers and contractors, and started terminating thousands of grants that did not fit the administration’s “America First” agenda. Secretary of State Marco Rubio had earlier exempted some of the relief programs from the pause for work deemed “lifesaving.” But a key payment system has remained largely offline, which has left aid partners without enough cash to continue their work and stranded thousands of pounds of food and medicine far from the communities desperate for help. On Tuesday, Ali gave officials his deadline for restarting payments. The Trump administration immediately appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, saying that disbursing nearly $2 billion payments would take weeks. Three hours before Ali’s deadline, a three-judge panel of the D.C. Circuit turned away the administration’s request, saying it does not have the right to appeal at this early stage of the litigation before the U.S. district judge has finished his work. At that point, the solicitor general’s office had already asked the Supreme Court to intervene. Harris told the justices that the government cannot function and the president cannot carry out his duties over foreign affairs if “a district court can appoint itself the claims-processor for the federal government and second-guess the Executive Branch’s determinations.” On Wednesday, the plaintiffs alleged that a small number of Trump’s political appointees, acting at the direction of Trump adviser Elon Musk, were refusing to authorize or vetoing the back payments to foreign aid. A Trump administration official said via email Wednesday evening that the State Department and USAID had just completed a review of its programming, identifying nearly $4.4 billion in grants for elimination. Nearly 5,800 awards were targeted for elimination as part of “the America First agenda,” the official said. USAID retained critical awards, including food assistance, lifesaving medical treatments for HIV, tuberculosis and malaria, and support for nations like Lebanon, Haiti, Venezuela and Cuba, the official said. The review had been ongoing when Ali “intervened” in the process, the official added, and the State Department and USAID moved “rapidly to complete the programmatic evaluation,” lifting stop-work orders for some programs and terminating others. Aid groups and contractors told The Washington Post on Wednesday that they were receiving government notices of thousands of aid projects being terminated, despite the federal judge’s ruling that foreign assistance should continue. John Hudson contributed to this report.

inputs.headline: Hegseth takes action against Trump foe Mark Milley
inputs.content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has decided to remove retired Gen. Mark A. Milley’s security detail, suspend his security clearance, and order an inspector general inquiry into his behavior as the Pentagon’s top officer, senior defense officials said Tuesday, taking extraordinary action against a frequent target of President Donald Trump. The move comes after years of Trump criticizing Milley for perceived disloyalty and Milley acknowledging in congressional testimony that he had served as a source for several unflattering books about the first Trump administration. Read the full story

inputs.headline: Treasury agrees to block DOGE’s access to personal taxpayer data at IRS
inputs.content: The Trump White House and Treasury Department officials have agreed to prohibit the U.S. DOGE Service from accessing personal taxpayer data, according to two people familiar with the arrangement, heading off a brewing privacy crisis at the tax agency. Gavin Kliger, a software engineer with Elon Musk’s DOGE effort assigned to the IRS, will have read-only access to anonymized tax data, the same access granted to academic researchers and IT professionals who work on IRS systems, said the people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to share details of the agreement. DOGE, which stands for the Department of Government Efficiency, over the weekend requested broad access to the most sensitive IRS data systems, which would have given Kliger the ability to see and in some cases edit detailed information — including bank accounts, payment balances, Social Security and other personal identification numbers and, in some instances, medical information — on virtually every individual, business and nonprofit in the country. White House officials argued that access was necessary to fulfill DOGE’s charge of rooting out government waste. But that information is some of the most heavily guarded data in the federal government. Political officials do not have access to the Integrated Data Retrieval System, or IDRS. The IRS’s commissioner, national taxpayer advocate and even senior officials in the office of the chief information officer do not have IDRS access either. The IRS was prepared to reject the White House’s request, the people said, on the grounds that allowing DOGE to have the information would put millions of taxpayers’ information at risk. But over the course of the week, Treasury officials recognized the broad nature of DOGE’s request and agreed to limit Kliger’s access, the people said. Representatives for the White House and Treasury Department did not immediately respond to requests for comment. DOGE has sought entry to several highly sensitive data systems across the government. The group sought access to the Treasury Department’s payment systems; the career official who was in charge of that program resigned rather than grant the request. He was later replaced by a DOGE staffer on assignment to Treasury. DOGE is also attempting to gain access to Social Security Administration datasets, which include the world’s largest repository of medical data and years of history on social safety net payments and employment histories. The acting Social Security administrator resigned late last week after clashing with DOGE officials over that request.

inputs.headline: Trump fires Federal Labor Relations Authority member
inputs.content: President Donald Trump fired Susan Tsui Grundmann, who until Tuesday served as chair of the Federal Labor Relations Authority, a White House official confirmed. Grundmann’s firing from the agency tasked with overseeing public-sector unions appears to violate federal law that protects the agency’s board members from removal by the president without cause. In recent days, Trump has also taken the extraordinary step of firing members of the National Labor Relations Board and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The unprecedented wave of firings appears to contravene a 1935 Supreme Court ruling that shields the leaders of independent agencies from removal by the president “except in cases of neglect of duty, malfeasance or inefficiency.” Grundmann’s term was set to expire in July. A White House official said about the firing that Trump is committed to building a team that advances his “America First” agenda. Everett Kelley, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, the largest federal workers’ union, said in a statement that Grundmann’s termination was “one more piece of evidence demonstrating this administration is engaged in a continued, unlawful attack on federal workers.”

inputs.headline: Trump backs off trade threats after Colombia agrees to deportation flights
inputs.content: The United States and Colombia averted a trade war, for now, after the White House said late Sunday that Bogotá agreed to accept deportation flights from the United States. The two nations had spent much of the day in a tense standoff, with President Donald Trump threatening to impose steep tariffs and visa restrictions on Colombia after the South American nation turned away two deportation flights. Read the full story
